channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistani Court Releases Militant Leader Tied to Mumbai Attacks on Bail
item.description: The release of the militant, Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, accused of orchestrating attacks that killed more than 160 people, is likely to further strain relations with India.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi was escorted by police officers after a court hearing in January in Islamabad, Pakistan.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Russian Poet Helps Ukraine Navigate Its New Identity
item.description: Boris Khersonsky, a psychiatrist and former Soviet dissident, has long advocated moving away from the idea that Ukrainian nationality should be determined by ethnicity.
item.dc:creator: SALLY McGRANE
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boris Khersonsky last month in his office in Odessa, Ukraine. He is a psychiatrist and poet with an increasingly influential voice in Ukraine’s intellectual circles.

item.title: The Young Hopes of Kenya, Laid in the Grave
item.description: The heavy weight of loss was evident in the Kenyan families who began to bury the students who were killed by the Shabab at Garissa University College.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: The body of Angela Nyokabi Githakwa, who was killed in the attack on Christian students at Garissa University College last week, was buried Friday at her father's ancestral farm in Wanugu, Kenya.

item.title: World Briefing: India Concludes Evacuation of Its Citizens From Yemen
item.description: Planes and naval vessels have evacuated 4,640 Indians and 960 foreign citizens since the effort began last month, India’s Ministry of External Affairs said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Pakistani Lawmakers Pass Resolution Urging Neutrality in Yemen Conflict
item.description: Analysts saw the decision as a significant setback for Saudi Arabia, which is leading a campaign of airstrikes against the Houthi movement in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Soldiers guarding the Parliament building in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Friday, when lawmakers unanimously passed a resolution on Yemen.

item.title: World Briefing: Palestinian Said to Be Killed by Israeli Soldiers
item.description: Israeli soldiers shot the man after a funeral procession turned into a violent confrontation in the southern West Bank.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: World Briefing: Czech Leader Won’t Attend Moscow Parade After Criticism
item.description: Reversing course, President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic said he would not attend a military parade commemorating the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe.
item.dc:creator: HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: Yemen’s War Leaves Aden Crumbling and Hungry
item.description: No place in the beleaguered country has suffered as severely as Aden, a blockaded port city captive to deadly street fighting for the better part of a month.
item.dc:creator: FATHI BIN-LAZRQ and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Supporters of the southern separatist movement during clashes with Houthi rebels on Wednesday in Aden, Yemen.

item.title: Obama and Cuba’s Raúl Castro Will Meet at Summit
item.description: President Obama also is nearing a decision on removing Cuba’s status as a sponsor of terrorism, citing progress in his push to re-establish ties.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: ISIS Kills 25 Police Officers and Soldiers in Iraqi Province of Anbar
item.description: The attackers overran large parts of Albu Faraj, less than two days after officials declared that they had begun an offensive against the extremists, the police said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The site of a car bombing that killed five civilians on Friday in the Karrada neighborhood of Baghdad.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Exploring the Fun Side of China’s War on Corruption
item.description: A growing comedic collection suggests that the Chinese have realized that President Xi Jinping’s effort to curb graft is no passing fad, and that they might as well have some fun with it.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wang Qishan, who heads the Communist Party's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, responsible for rooting out corruption, has figured as a character in Chinese jokes.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fan Dashes Across Track During Practice at Chinese Grand Prix
item.description: The man reportedly wanted to “try a car” and was detained by members of the security staff when he reached the Ferrari garage.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Letter from America: Bush Follows a Harder but Happier Path
item.description: For a Republican presidential front-runner, Jeb Bush has an unusual array of vulnerabilities, but appears at peace with his obstacles.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARWOOD

item.title: Richie Benaud, Commentator Whose Native Tongue Was Cricket, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Benaud, a former captain of Australia, was a uniquely authoritative television voice, explaining the action with dry wit, perception and economy.
item.dc:creator: HUW RICHARDS
item.media:description: Richie Benaud was called “perhaps the most influential cricketer and cricket personality since the Second World War” by Gideon Haigh, one of the sport's most authoritative chroniclers.

item.title: Head-On Collision of Truck and Bus Kills 33 in Morocco
item.description: A semi-trailer truck and a bus carrying a delegation of young athletes crashed, killing dozens of people, according to local news reports.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Is Rapidly Adding Coast Guard Ships, U.S. Navy Says
item.description: China has the world’s largest Coast Guard fleet, with more ships than Japan, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines combined, a report shows.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A China Coast Guard vessel last year. China has increased its number of Coast Guard ships by 25 percent in the last three years.

item.title: China Is Said to Use Powerful New Weapon to Censor Internet
item.description: The tool allows Beijing to intercept foreign web traffic and inject malicious code, and it could have more powerful capabilities.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: The Great Cannon system was used to intercept web and advertising traffic intended for Baidu, China’s biggest search engine company, researchers said.

item.title: Environmental Order in China to Prevent Building of Contested Dam
item.description: The directive to ban new dams on part of the Yangtze River will scuttle a large project near Chongqing that environmentalists had protested for years.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Statement on Its Construction in the South China Sea
item.description: During a regularly scheduled news conference, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman was asked about the infrastructure China has been constructing around reefs, rocks and shoals in waters of the South China Sea that are claimed by other countries.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Center for Strategic and International Studies, via Digital Globe
item.media:description: A satellite image from March 16 shows dredging at the northernmost reclamation site of Mischief Reef, part of the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Mocking Mao Backfires for Chinese TV Host
item.description: Tipsy gibes by the Chinese television celebrity Bi Fujian caught on video have been enough to inspire tirades from the state media and imperil Mr. Bi’s career.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
